content: N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 83.
Accustomed rags preferred to new garments.

A Brahmin returns home to find a palace instead of a
cottage; he recognizes his wife only after she throws off her jewels and
ornaments to stand before him in her old rags. India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Former poverty chosen over new riches.

Weaver laments loss of water vessel. Offered many new, but
prefers old and modest life. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
The worst horse, armor, or the like proves best. *Fb
”hest“ I 598b; Child II 444f., 450, 453f.; German: Grimm No. 57; Spanish:
Espinosa Jr. Nos. 62, 64; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese:
Graham; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 341, (Arikara): Dorsey CI XVII No. 16;
West Indies: Flowers 559.
child:
Saint, offered any gift from God, chooses (virginity and)
wisdom.
Solomon, offered any gift from God, chooses wisdom.
Granted wisdom and wealth. Irish myth: Cross.
Hero prefers fame to long life.
Modest choice proves good (simple unique privilege).

Girl offered reward of five villages chooses rather to be
only one on certain night to be allowed to have light in her house and to keep
all animals who enter as hers. All kinds of livestock come. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content: Poor girl chosen rather than the rich.

Treasure follows. Chauvin III 103 No. 13; Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
child:
Modest choice best: wife chosen from crowd of women--only
one poorly dressed.
Choice of ugliest girl as bride.

content:
Objects from which
choice is to be made are hidden in caskets (or the like). The worst looking
casket proves to be the best choice. Type 480; *Cox 501ff.; Cosquin Lorraine
No. 17; *Chauvin III 99 No. 4; *Crane Vitry 153 No. 47; *Oesterley No. 251;
*Roberts 200; *Cosquin Contes indiens 527; Boccaccio Decameron X No. 1 (Lee
294); *Ward II 122; Herbert III 196; *Wesselski Märchen 213 No. 18; *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 836; *Fb ”skål“ III 352a. -- North Carolina: Brown Collection I 633; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese:
Graham; Japanese: Anesaki 320; N. A. Indian (Arikara): Dorsey CI XVII No. 16,
(Nez Percé): Spinden JAFL XXI 156, (Carib): Alexander Lat. Am. 264; Malay: V.
Ronkel Catalogus der Maleische Handschriften te Batavia (Den Haag, 1909) 48;
Africa (Angola): Chatelain 121 No. 10, 229 No. 41, (Benga): Nassau 225 No. 33.

Prosperity forever or for a day? King asks prince whether
he has secret of prosperity forever or a day.

Prince says ”forever“ and is captured. Later his wife, asked same
question, says ”for a day“ and is honored. India: Thompson-Balys.

Rides away without it. *Types 300, 303; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 7;
Icelandic: Boberg.
Beggar with small bag surpasses the one with the large.

Latter refuses all but large donations; gets none. Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 607; *Crane Vitry 168 No. 77; Alphabet No. 607.

Small gift with blessing preferred to large gift with
parent’s
curse. *Köhler-Bolte I 188; BP I 214 n. 1; Gunkel Das Märchen im alten
Testament (Tübingen, 1921) 100f.; Campbell Tales I 220 No. 13; Lang English
Fairy Tales 136 No. 23; Gipsy: Aichele Zigeunermärchen 289 No. 69; Jewish:
Neuman; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 110, 122.
child: Modest choice for parting gift--money or counsels.

Counsels chosen. Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas III 100,
304.
Modest parting gift best--meat or bones.

Bones thrown to pursuing dogs delay them and allow escape;
not so with meat. India: Thompson-Balys.

Modest choice for parting gift: when offered money man
takes magic stick.
Modest choice of parting gift: magic iron measure chosen.

content: Modest request: present from the journey.

Asked what her father shall bring her as a present, the
heroine chooses a modest gift. It is usually a flower but sometimes does not
turn out to be such a simple gift after all (golden cloak, golden apple). *Type
425; *Fb ”rose“ III 80a, ”guldæble“ I 515b, ”guldrok“ I 514b; *Hdwb. d.
Märchens I 206b; Tegethoff 11; Italian Basile Pentamerone II No. 8; India:
Thompson-Balys.
child: Present from the journey: what you first see.

content:
Always has good luck. *Type 1650; BP II 69ff.; MacCulloch Childhood 365; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Eskimo (Greenland): Rink 93, 281, 434, (Central Eskimo): Boas
RBAE VI 630, (Ungava): Turner RBAE XI 265, (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 309,
(Kodiak): Golder JAFL XVI 16.
child:
Seal of humiliation put by youngest brother-in-law on the
back of his rivals.
”Thirteen“ as name of victorious youngest son.

(Youngest of thirteen
brothers.) BP III 34; *Köhler-Bolte I 383; India: Thompson-Balys.
Abused son of younger co-wife becomes hero.

content:
Kind to people or
animals: rewarded. *Types 513, 550, 551, 570, 571, 577, 610; Missouri French:
Carrière; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian (Klikitat):
Jacobs U Wash II 10.
child:
Youngest wife’s son restores eyesight to blinded six wives
of raja and reinstates his mother.

content:
Panzer Beowulf passim; N. A. Indian (Micmac, Shuswap):
Thompson CColl II 416ff.

child:
See references to †L52 and †L55. *Roberts
137; Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 142--145; Greek:
Grote I 103.

Youngest daughter agrees to marry a monster; later the
sisters are jealous.

*Type 425; India:
Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 199 No. 76.

content:
Types 516, 550; Rösch
FFC LXXVII 96; Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 130; India:
Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham.

*Types 425, 510, 511, 709; *Cox 492ff.;
Böklen 78ff.; *Roberts 110; Tegethoff 10; Icelandic: Boberg; Italian Novella:
Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 248 No. 193; Hawaii:
Beckwith Myth 170 n. 5; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/346). Most references to
†L50 apply to this motif.

Elder have been deceived. N. A. Indian (Pawnee): Dorsey CI
LIX 166 No. 44, (Kwakiut): Boas and Hunt JE X 196ff.; (Takelma): Sapir U Pa II
(1) 64 No. 4, (Modoc): Curtin Myths of the Modocs (Boston, 1912) 27ff., (Yana):
Curtin Creation Myths (Boston, 1898) 353ff.

Elder sisters have been deceived. Type 883B; Italian:
Basile Pentamerone III No. 4; India: Thompson-Balys.
Youngest animal in group overcomes adversary.
N. A. Indian (Klikitat): Jacobs U Wash II 7--9.

Only the youngest of group of imprisoned women refuses to
eat her newborn child.
Younger brother given birthright of elder.

Only the youngest brother helps his sister perform
dangerous task.

Wild animal finds his liberty better than tame animal‘s
ease.
child:
The tame bird tells the wild one to look about him. He is shot. Type 245;
Japanese: Ikeda.
Wild ass envies tame ass until he sees his burdens.

Wienert FFC LVI 59 (ST 198), 124 (ST 328); Halm Aesop No.
321.

Wolf prefers liberty and hunger to dog’s servitude and
plenty.

*Type 201; Crane Vitry 221 No.
217; Wienert FFC LVI 61 (ET 238), 124 (ST 326); Halm Aesop No. 278; Jacobs
Aesop 206 No. 28; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 433; Scala Celi 76b No. 435; Italian
Novella: Rotunda; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Parrot prefers cold wet nest in freedom to luxury in royal
palace.

content: Ass is jealous of the horse until he learns better.
child:
Ass jealous of horse, but sees horse later working in a
mill.
Ass jealous of war-horse until he sees him wounded.

Wienert FFC LVI 58 (ET 191), 124 (ST 327); Halm Aesop No.
328; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content:
Mule carrying corn escapes while one carrying gold is
robbed.
Lean dogs envy arena-dog his fatness.

Later see their error. Wienert FFC LVI 56 (ET 169), 94 (ST
75).
Calf pities draft ox: is taken to slaughter, ox spared.

Wienert FFC LVI 61 (ET 230), 57 (ET 185), *92 (ST 44), 124
(ST 331); Halm Aesop No. 113.

Arrogant farmer allows none to ride his precious horse
without permission.

He kills the man who
does it, but is in revenge deprived of most of his goods. Icelandic: Hrafnkels
saga Freysgods ch. 2ff. (ed. F. S. Cawley) (Cambridge, Mass., 1932).
King vainly forbids tide to rise.
child:
King vainly attempts to measure the height of the sky and
the depth of the sea.

content:
God punishes David for his pride in the number of his
subjects.

An angel is sent to kill his
people. Desists only when David repents. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
God finds that his statue sells at low price.

He prices it in a statue shop and finds that his price is
lower than other gods. Wienert FFC LVI 80 (ET 455), 94 (ST 77); Halm Aesop No.
137.
Attempt to fly to heaven punished.
Car supported by eagles. Persian: Carnoy 336.
child: Attempt to climb to heaven punished.
Man sets self up as a god. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Peter acts as God for a day: tires of bargain.

A girl takes her goat to pasture and leaves him: ”My God
care for you!“ Peter must run everywhere after the goat. *Dh II 188.

Dream (prophecy) of future greatness causes banishment
(imprisonment).

Man who has never known unhappiness or want is swallowed up
by earth with all his household.
Poor man aspires to high office: made a cook.

child:
Proud king humbled: realizes that pomp, possessions, power
are all of short duration.
King, defeated in battle, obliged to flee without money.
Boasting king insulted by crow dropping filth on him.
Defeated king must be peddler or beggar.
Queen forced to become a courtesan.

content:
When well fed says, ”My mother was a thoroughbred horse.“
Later, hard worked, says, ”My father was a miserable ass.“ Wienert FFC LVI 64
(ET 275), 94 (ST 80); Halm Aesop No. 157.
Proud inscriptions sole remains of powerful king.

*Chauvin V 33 No. 16; Spanish Exempla: Keller. Cf.
Shelley‘s ”Ozymandias“.
Stag scorns his legs but is proud of his horns.

Caught by his horns in trees. *Type 77; Wienert FFC LVI 65
(ET 285), 140 (ST 465); Halm Aesop No. 128; *Crane Vitry 254 No. 274; Herbert
III 23; Jacobs Aesop 206 No. 25.
Fox destroys nest of bird who boasts of nest‘s warmth.
Men too prosperous (happy): things are made more difficult.
child: Men are too rich: greedy gods created to impoverish them.
Men are too rich: gold sent below ground.
Men are too rich: weeds created to spoil their harvests.
Men are too proud: snakes created.
Men are fearless: tiger made to frighten them.
Men enjoy themselves too much: disease created.

content: Impoverished husband begs from wife‘s new husband.

He has formerly refused this man charity. *Chauvin II 174
No. 16, VIII 180 No. 212; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 263 N. 232; *Basset
1001 Contes II 305.
child: Cruel brothers brought to beg charity from abused sister.

Impoverished father begs from daughter he has banished:
recognized.

Impoverished father begs from his prosperous daughter whom he
has made to marry a poor man.

Impoverished husband begs from wife he has formerly
expelled.

Impoverished youngest brother comes to elders in search of
work.

content: Zeus smites Capaneus while he is climbing a ladder.
Pride or wealth of man brought low by actions of gods.

King commanded to wear enemy’s shoes on his shoulders as
sign of submission.
child: Proud king humbled when imprisoned by enemies.

content: The man scorns the storm: killed by it.

Jackal singing about his deeds falls down from tree and is
eaten by alligator.

(King in the bath.)
While the king is in the bath (or hunting) an angel in his form takes his
place. The king is repulsed on all sides until he repents of his haughtiness.
*Type 757; **Varnhagen Ein indisches Märchen auf seine Wanderung durch die
asiatischen und europäischen Literaturen (Berlin, 1882); Chauvin II 161 No. 51;
*Wesselski Märchen 237 No. 49; Hibbard 58ff.; *Herbert III 202; *Oesterley No.
59; *Andraea Anglia Beiblatt XIII 302; *von der Hagen III cxv; bin Gorion Born
Judas III 47ff., 299f.; *Goebel Jüdische Motive im Märchenhafte Erzählungsgut
(Gleiwitz, 1932) 89ff. -- Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Icelandic: Boberg; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Rich man made poor to punish pride.

He boasts that God has no power to make him poor. While he
is at church, his property burns and he returns home poor. Type 836; Irish:
Beal XXI 336, O’Suilleabhain 122; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas II 249; India:
Thompson-Balys.
child:
Woman casts ring into sea boasting that it is as impossible
for her to become poor as for the ring to be found.

Ring is found in fish: she becomes poor. W. Jones
Finger-Ring Lore (London, 1898) 440; Finnish-Swedish: Wessman 19 No. 178.

content: Oil lamp blown out: had thought that it outshone stars.

Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET 409), 93 (ST 64); Halm Aesop No.
285.
Gnats having overcome lion are in turn killed by spider.

Wienert FFC LVI 48 (ET 75), 92 (ST 57); Halm Aesop No.
234.

child:
He has said of a
condemned man that he deserves his punishment. *Types 756A, 756B; BP III
463ff.; *Andrejev FFC LXIX 160ff., 250ff.; Wesselski Mönchslatein 21 No. 16;
Alphabet No. 206; Irish: O’Suilleabhain 99,
Beal XXI 332; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos 79f.

Abbot tells him to search his own heart to see if he is
free of sin before attacking others. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

She has passed judgment
on a girl who has a bastard. Köhler-Bolte I 147f., *578, 581.
Woman with three hundred sixty-five children.

Punished for
self-righteous condemnation of unchaste girl. *Taylor Notes and Queries No. 251
(Feb., 1923) 96; *K. Nyrop Grevinden med de 365 Born (København, 1909); Zs. f.
Vksk. XIX 469; Child II 67f., IV 463b.; *Köhler Lais der Marie de France@2 xc;
*DeCock Volkssage 9ff.

Throws God‘s footstool at an old woman thief on earth.
*Type 800; BP I 342; Wesselski Bebel I 126 No. 19.
The beggar on the cross in place of Christ.

Is made to leave the cross for his impatience concerning
the sinners. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 800A*.

content: King shown he is less powerful than God.

In spite of all his plans, his servant recovers the lost
(exchanged) treasure. Type 841.

child: Both served up at same meal. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Arrogant mistress repaid in kind by her lover.
child:
Haughty mistress makes extravagant demands of lover:
repaid.

Scorned lover poses as rich man and cheats his scornful
mistress.

Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 10
(Lee 266); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Sneering princess is impregnated by magic.

content: Daughter succeeds on quest where son fails.

Africa (Rozwi): Posselt Fables of the Veld (Oxford, 1929)
30ff.
Disagreeable and disliked child surpasses the likeable one.

Scorning stops when it turns out that the scorned has saved
the king by fighting alone against four.
Unpromising hero kills those who scorn him.
Unpromising hero must live in hut.
Unpromising son leaves his home and goes into the world.

*Type 314; Cox Nos. 1, 33, 77, 79, and passim; Chinese:
Graham; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 351.

*Cox 1--52, 87--121, 437, 446, 493; *Fb ”askefis“ IV 17b;
Saintyves Perrault 124ff.; *Cosquin Contes indiens 494ff.; Tupper and Ogle
Walter Map 115; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 119; Italian:
Basile Pentamerone I No. 6; Chinese: Graham; N. A. Indian (Micmac): Michelson
JAFL XXXVIII 45ff.

child:
Fugitive bull-calf returns when grown and defeats his
father.

*Dickson 144ff. n. 147; Hdwb. d. Märchens II 120b; Irish myth:
Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Missouri-French: Carrière; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda; Tonga: Gifford 130; N. A. Indian: Lowie JAFL XXI 27.
Future hero found in boat (basket, bushes).

Legends of Moses, Cyrus,
Beowulf and others. *Usener Die Sintfluthsagen (Bonn, 1899) 80ff.; Hdwb. d.
Märchens I s.v. ”Aussetzung in Boot“; Icelandic: *Boberg;
Missouri French: Carrière; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman; India:
Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.

Future heroine found in hollow tree (calfshed, house
”without door but only window and skylight“).

Icelandic: *Boberg; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Tonga:
Gifford 122.
Future hero found on top of a tree.
Future hero found in wolf den.

*Jacobs‘s list s.v. ”Widow’s son“; *Krappe Balor 126ff.; Garnett FL III 265; Missouri French:
Carrière; India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham.

Missouri French: Carrière; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese:
Graham; New Hebrides: Codrington 283ff.; Buin: Wheeler No. 8; Tuamotu: Stimson
MS (T-G. 3/818); Africa (Wakweli): Bender 81.

Avenges slaughtered kin. N. A. Indian: Thompson Tales 320
n. 156 (most of the references).

India:
*Thompson-Balys; Africa (Mossi): Frobenius Atlantis VIII 274ff. No. 120.

Eskimo (Greenland): Rink 93, Rasmussen I 123, 230, 238, II 34, 38, III 90, 295,
(Cumberland Sound): Boas BAM XV 188, (West Hudson Bay): ibid. 309, (Ungava):
Turner RBAE XI 265, (Central Eskimo): Boas RBAE VI 630.

Icelandic:
Boberg; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 957; Africa (Nuba): Reinisch Sprachen von
Nord-Ost-Africa (Wien, 1879) II 224ff. No. 9.
Heroes sons of wife not favorite of king.
Heroine daughter of wife not favorite of king.
Hero of story neglected grandson of raja.

Type 594*; *Cox xl, 437--446; Missouri French: Carrière; India:
Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian (Micmac): Rand 440 No. 85, (Zuñi): Parsons MAFL
XXXI 245.
Heroine endures hardships with menial husband.

Rewarded by his success.
BP I 443ff.; cf. Type 900; Cosquin Lorraine I 138ff.; Missouri French:
Carrière; India: *Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl 348ff.,
(Blackfoot): Wissler and Duvall PaAM II 81, (Wichita): Dorsey JAFL XVI 160ff.,
(Teton): Curtis N. A. Indian III 111, cf. Eskimo (Kodiak): Golder JAFL XVI 16.

(Cf. †P412.2.) Hdwb. d. Märchens I 186b n. 109; Irish myth:
*Cross:

Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. ”garçon“; Missouri French:
Carrière.

Cox 1-121 passim; BP I 183; Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish:
Espinosa Jr. No. 119; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Africa (Nubian): Rochemonteix Quelques Contes Nubiens (Cairo, 1888) 48ff. No.
4, (Suaheli): Steere 13ff.

*Type
708; *BP II 236; Cosquin Lorraine II 224; India: Thompson-Balys.
Loathly man father of supernaturally born boy.

S. A. Indian
(Chiriguano): Métraux MAFLS XL 159.

Type 301; Missouri French: Carrière; Chinese: Graham; N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 327 n. 183.

N. A. Indian (Pawnee): Dorsey CI LIX Nos. 42, 44, 47, Grinnell 87ff., (Skidi
Pawnee): Dorsey MAFLS VIII No. 9, (Arikara): Dorsey CI XVII Nos. 17--19,
(Hidatsa): Curtis N. A. Indian IV 165.

N. A. Indian (Blackfoot): Grinnell Blackfoot Lodge Tales (New York, 1892) 93,
McClintock Old North Trail (London, 1910) 491.

Africa (Basuto): Kidd The Bull of the Kraal and the Heavenly Maidens (London,
1908) 51ff. No. 1.

content:
N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 327f. nn.
185f. (many references), (Zuñi): *Benedict II 336.
Lowly successful hero invites king and humbles him.
child: Lowly successful soldier invites general and humbles him.

Ape tries to flee with favorite child; neglected child
saves himself.

The favorite child is
killed through the mother’s overanxiety. Wienert FFC LVI 62 (ET 253), 146 (ST
510); Halm Aesop No. 366.
Tardy bird alone succeeds at bird convocation.
Ignorant steward straightens his master’s accounts.

The educated stewards have always cheated. The ignorant
puts his belongings in one box, his master‘s in another. Both master and
steward gain. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 355.

Farmer surpasses astronomer and doctor in predicting weather
and choosing food.

Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 2448*; Russian: Andrejev No. 2132; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 921
II*.

content: *Fb ”mester“ II 584a; Alphabet No. 38; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

child: Poor girl chosen as wife in preference to rich.
Poor suitor makes good husband; rich suitor cruel.

content:
Missouri French:
Carrière; Chinese: Graham; West Indies: Flowers 559.
child: The stupid monk recovers the stolen flocks.

A nobleman steals the abbot’s flocks, saying that the
monks have no use for them since they eat no meat. The most learned of the
monks tries to recover them, but without success. The most stupid is then sent.
Asked to dinner, he eats till he can hold no more. He tells the nobleman that
he ate as much as possible since he could take back with him only what he had
in his stomach. The nobleman pleased with the reply returns the flocks. Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 61; Alphabet No. 718; Mensa Philosophica No. 187.

Simpleton‘s naive answer to robbers makes them think he
knows their secret.

They share their loot
with him. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Hero stupid at games but fleet of foot.
Eskimo (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 214.
If you hasten you will not get there.

In spite of the saint‘s advice the teamster hastens and
breaks his wagon. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 255; Alphabet No. 324.

content:
(Cf. †Z253.) Icelandic: *Boberg; Missouri French: Carrière;
Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 131; India: *Thompson-Balys.

child:
Loved
by a courtesan, he proves later to be a great man. M. Bloomfield in Penzer VII
xxiii.

Famous poet does not speak until he is fourteen (four,
seven) years old.

content:
Usually, but not always, the youngest
daughter. See references to †L50. *BP I 165ff.; **Cox passim; Irish myth:
Cross; Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. ”merle“; Missouri French:
Carrière: Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/346); N. A.
Indian (Zuñi): Benedict II 336.

Usually, but not always,
the unpromising hero is also the youngest son. *BP I 183ff.; *Rank Mythus v. d.
Geburt d. Helden; *Cosquin Contes indiens 494ff.; Cox 437--462, 519; M.
Bloomfield in Penzer VII x; *Hdwb. d. Märchens I 184b nn. 13ff.; Chauvin II 83
No. 9.-- Icelandic: *Boberg; English: Wells 25 (The Tale of Gamelyn); Missouri
French: Carrière; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 52 No.
32; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 408; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 327 n. 185; Africa
(Fang): Trilles 251f.
child:
Irish myth: Cross; N. A.
Indian (Zuñi): Benedict II 336.

content:
*Types 300, 301, 302, 303, 304, 306, 307, 308*, 314, 325,
329, 400, 434, 502, 506, 507, 508, 513, 514, 530, 545B, 552, 553, 559, 560,
561, 570, 571, 575, 577, 580, 590, 594*, 725, 853, 854, 930, 935; Child V 488
s.v. ”marriages“.--Missouri French: Carrière; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham; Japanese: Ikeda; Tahiti: Henry Ancient Tahiti
(Honolulu, 1928) 614.
child: Marriage of poor boy and rich girl.
Fool wins beautiful woman as wife.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 530B*; India: Thompson-Balys.
Mercenary soldier (exile) accepted lover of princess.

content:
*Types 310, 403, 428,
431, 440, 442, 450, 451, 501, 510, 511, 545A, 585, 652, 705, 706, 707, 708,
711, 870A, 873, 875, 883A, 887; Hibbard 190ff.; *Roberts 196. -- Irish myth:
*Cross; Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 107f., 154,
Espinosa Jr. Nos. 80, 142; Italian: Basile Pentamerone III No. 5 and passim,
*Rotunda; India: Cowell Jataka I 27f., *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera
I 147, 423, II 103, 455, 1366; Japanese: Ikeda.

child:
Types
301, 650; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian (California):
Gayton and Newman 95.

content: Unpromising hero given great powers by deity.
Little strong man defeats giant in race.

*Type 328; A. Stender-Petersen Acta Jutlandica VI (1934)
166ff.; Irish myth: Cross; English: Child II 35ff.; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Japanese: Anesaki 311; Jewish:
Neuman, I Samuel 17:23 (David and Goliath); N. A. Indian (Southern Paiute,
Shivwits): Lowie JAFL XXXVII 150 No. 17; Guatamala Indian (Quiche): Alexander
Lat. Am. 168ff.; Tuamotu: Beckwith Myth 476.
child: Poorly-armed hero overcomes well-armed by strategy.
Little innocent girl is able to drive giant out of land.

content: Little fishes escape from the net.

The large are caught. *Type 253; *BP III 355; Wienert FFC
LVI 66 (ET 299), 113 (ST 240); Halm Aesop No. 26.

Offended rats gnaw saddle girths of king’s horses so that
he is defeated in battle.

Hummingbird can see fowler’s net; eagle is caught in spite
of his boasts of good eyesight.

*Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 290; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 254*.
Mice escape into their holes; weasels cannot follow them.

Wienert FFC LVI 48 (ET 65), *113 (ST 241); Halm Aesop No.
291.

Bride asks suitors what they have to offer her. Poor youth who has nothing but
love to offer gets her. India: Thompson-Balys.
Mouse stronger than wall, wind, mountain.

*DeCock Volkssage 31ff.;
BP I 148 n. 2; Wesselski Mönchslatein 82 No. 75; Chauvin II 97 No. 55; Archiv
f. d. Studium d. neueren Sprachen LXXXI 265; Germania II 481; Basset RTP VII
394ff.; Basset Contes Berbères 95f; *Bødker Exempler 297 No. 60.--Spanish: Keller,
Espinosa III Nos. 275--277; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese:
Ikeda.
child:
Mosquitoes sting King Pharaoh and show they are stronger
than the man who cannot escape them.
Reed pricks and drives away dog that urinates on it.

content:
Frog, tortoise, fish each tell of how long they expect to
live.

Frog alone does not expect to live
to a hundred and ten years and alone escapes fisherman’s net. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Slow flying swan lasts longer than speedy crow in flying.

Goldsmith gives money to one who addressed him as friend
(the goldsmith had no friends because he has cheated everybody.)
Priest who gives mild penances succeeds where others fail.

Scala Celi 48a No. 272; Alphabet No. 183; Herbert III 505,
570; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Gives everyone the same measure of wit, so that the smaller are more clever
than the large. Wienert FFC LVI 35; Halm Aesop No. 150.

child: Bird flies into large animal‘s ear and kills him.

*Type 228; *BP II 437; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia:
DeVries’s list No. 115.
Mouse runs into buffalo‘s ear and overcomes him.
Mouse torments bull who cannot catch him.
Fox burns tree in which eagle has nest.

Revenges theft of cub. Herbert III 12; *Crane Vitry 194
No. 144.
Revenges theft of her young. *Crane Vitry 194 No. 143.
Lark causes elephant to fall over precipice.

Chauvin II 81 No. 1; India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera II 771; Japanese: Ikeda.

Elephant killed by mouse who runs up open end of trunk to
head and there smears poison over his brain.
Insects worry large animal to despair or death.

Wienert FFC LVI *48 (ET 76), 120 (ST 301); Spanish:
Espinosa Jr. Nos. 187, 209; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries’s list Nos.
132, 137.

Eagle at last goes to the sky and lays eggs in Zeus’s lap.
The dungbeetle causes Zeus to shake his apron and break the eggs. Wienert FFC
LVI *51 (ET 106), 77 (ET 432), 113 (ST 237), 114 (ST 249); Halm Aesop No. 7.
Fish pricks monster with fins and defeats him.
Falcon attacks eagle repeatedly and defeats him.

Hedgehog defeats tiger by jumping into tiger‘s mouth and
tormenting him.
Small animals dupe larger into trap.

content:
Survives him and inherits property. Africa (Fang): Tessman
191ff.

child:
Rain also tries unsuccessfully like wind. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Sun cursed by man for its burning rays, wind for its hot
breath, but moon is blessed for its soft, cool, and beautiful light.

Mildness triumphs over violence: queen advises husband to
use kindness to enemies.

This wins them
over where war failed. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Saint uses kind words to pagan priest who has just smitten
a Christian.

This causes pagan to repent.
Conversion follows. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
